questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : AI: SEARCH METHODS FOR PROBLEM SOLVING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : AI: SEARCH METHODS FOR PROBLEM SOLVING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1:
SEARCH

Figure shows an infinite state space with finite branching, where S is the start node and G is the goal node, and G is at the center of a unit circle, and the remaining nodes are on the unit circle. (Note: circular grid is shown by dashed lines which are not part of the state space.)
questions.question_text_2: SEARCH Figure shows an infinite state space with finite branching, where S is the start node and G is the goal node, and G is at the center of a unit circle, and the remaining nodes are on the unit circle. (Note: circular grid is shown by dashed lines which are not part of the state space.) Take the radial distance as the heuristic value: h(G)=0; h(S)=1; and h(Ak)=1, for all k in {1, 2, . . .}. MoveGen returns neighbours in alphabetical order (A1,A2,..., G,S). Tie-breaker: use alphabetical order to break ties. Note: sum(1, a, a^2, a^3, ..., a^(n-1)) is given by ((1 - a^n)/(1 - a)). Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions

questions.question_text_1:
TSP

The distance matrix for 5 cities (A to E) and the sorted edge list is provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, in row one, the distance from A to B is 30, A to C is 32 and so on.
questions.question_text_2:
TSP

The distance matrix for 5 cities (A to E) and the sorted edge list is provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, in row one, the distance from A to B is 30, A to C is 32 and so on. 
  The search tree traversed by TSP BnB shows four segments. Identify the four segments xy, uv, rs, pq and then answer the given sub-questions.
questions.question_text_3: TSP The distance matrix for 5 cities (A to E) and the sorted edge list is provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, in row one, the distance from A to B is 30, A to C is 32 and so on. The search tree traversed by TSP BnB shows four segments. Identify the four segments xy, uv, rs, pq and then answer the given sub-questions. Attention: A segment is a two-way edge between two cities. After adding/dropping a permanent segment, infer as many new permanent segments as possible before computing the lower bound.

The distance matrix for 5 cities (A to E) and the sorted edge list is provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, in row one, the distance from A to B is 30, A to C is 32 and so on. 
  The search tree traversed by TSP BnB shows four segments. Identify the four segments xy, uv, rs, pq and then answer the given sub-questions.
parent_question.question_text_3: TSP The distance matrix for 5 cities (A to E) and the sorted edge list is provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, in row one, the distance from A to B is 30, A to C is 32 and so on. The search tree traversed by TSP BnB shows four segments. Identify the four segments xy, uv, rs, pq and then answer the given sub-questions. Attention: A segment is a two-way edge between two cities. After adding/dropping a permanent segment, infer as many new permanent segments as possible before computing the lower bound.
question_texts: TSP The distance matrix for 5 cities (A to E) and the sorted edge list is provided below. For each city the distances to other cities are listed in ascending order. For example, in row one, the distance from A to B is 30, A to C is 32 and so on. TSP The distance matrix for 5 cities (A to E) and the sorted edge list is provided below. The search tree traversed by TSP BnB shows four segments. Identify the four segments xy, uv, rs, pq and then answer the given sub-questions. After adding/dropping a permanent segment, infer as many new permanent segments as possible before computing the lower bound.

questions.question_text_1: AUTOMATED PLANNING The domain description of a Blocks World with a single one-armed robot is given below. Note: this is the same domain description used in the weekly assignments.
questions.question_text_2: AUTOMATED PLANNING The domain description of a Blocks World with a single one-armed robot is given below. Note: this is the same domain description used in the weekly assignments. Tie-breaker: When actions are chosen non-deterministically, choose actions that lead to a plan. Throw away the actions that lead to dead-ends or cycles. Tie-breaker: Treat the goal description, preconditions and effects as lists that are accessed from left to right. When the elements in a list are pushed one by one to a stack, the last element in the list will be at the top of the stack. It has the effect of reversing the list. A planning problem is given below, find a plan using the operators and predicates defined in the blocks-world domain.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. Search Algorithms
- **Breadth-First Search (BFS)**: Explores all neighbors at the present depth before moving on to nodes at the next depth level.
- **Best-First Search**: Uses a priority queue to explore the most promising node first, based on a given heuristic.
- **Branch and Bound**: An algorithm for discrete and combinatorial optimization problems. It systematically enumerates candidate solutions and abandons a candidate ("branches") if it cannot possibly be better than the best solution found so far ("bounds").
- **A* Algorithm**: Combines the benefits of BFS and Best-First Search by using a cost function `f(n) = g(n) + h(n)`, where `g(n)` is the cost to reach node `n` and `h(n)` is the heuristic estimate to reach the goal from node `n`.
- **Weighted A* (wA*)**: A variant of A* where the heuristic is weighted by a factor `w`.

#### 2. Heuristics
- **Admissible Heuristic**: A heuristic that never overestimates the cost to reach the goal.
- **Heuristic Function**: A function that estimates the cost from a given state to the goal state. For example, radial distance in a unit circle.

#### 3. Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP)
- **Distance Matrix**: A matrix representing the distances between cities.
- **Branch and Bound for TSP**: Uses a search tree to explore possible tours and prunes branches that cannot lead to an optimal solution.
- **Lower Bound**: The minimum possible cost of a tour.
- **Upper Bound**: The maximum possible cost of a tour.

#### 4. Game Theory
- **Alpha-Beta Pruning**: An optimization technique for the minimax algorithm that reduces the number of nodes evaluated in the search tree.
- **Alpha-Cut and Beta-Cut**: Techniques used in Alpha-Beta pruning to eliminate branches in the search tree.
- **Horizon Nodes**: Nodes at the deepest level of the search tree.
- **SSS* Algorithm**: A state-space search algorithm that uses a heuristic to guide the search.

#### 5. Automated Planning
- **Predicates and Operators**: Definitions of actions and their preconditions and effects.
- **Goal Stack Planning**: An algorithm that uses a stack to keep track of subgoals and actions.
- **Optimal Plan**: A sequence of actions that achieves the goal with the least cost.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Search Algorithms] --> B[Breadth-First Search]
    A --> C[Best-First Search]
    A --> D[Branch and Bound]
    A --> E[A* Algorithm]
    A --> F[Weighted A*]
    B --> G[Explores all neighbors]
    C --> H[Uses priority queue]
    D --> I[Systematic enumeration]
    E --> J[Cost function f(n) = g(n) + h(n)]
    F --> K[Weighted heuristic]

    L[Heuristics] --> M[Admissible Heuristic]
    L --> N[Heuristic Function]

    O[Traveling Salesman Problem] --> P[Distance Matrix]
    O --> Q[Branch and Bound for TSP]
    O --> R[Lower Bound]
    O --> S[Upper Bound]

    T[Game Theory] --> U[Alpha-Beta Pruning]
    T --> V[Alpha-Cut and Beta-Cut]
    T --> W[Horizon Nodes]
    T --> X[SSS* Algorithm]

    Y[Automated Planning] --> Z[Predicates and Operators]
    Y --> AA[Goal Stack Planning]
    Y --> AB[Optimal Plan]
```
